Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 03:02PM - edited Jan 15, 2011 03:11PM by redskies Hi Debra, I had a few small liver mets, after a couple months on xeloda (even after dose reductions) they could not be seen.  Stopped xeloda due to hand-foot syndrome after 4 months, had a small amount of progression in my lymph nodes on faslodex for  several months, now have a new lession on my liver.  My onc strongly recommended a taxane, but also mentioned a research trial, and I decided to go with that; if I hadn't I would have tried abraxane, a taxane which tends to have fewer nasty se, and is quicker to administer (no premeds needed.) Best of luck, Lynne P.S. My onc said you can receive a higher dose on abraxane than paclitaxol, because abraxane is more tolerable- seems like a big plus when fighting liver mets!
Posts.Title: Calling All Liver Mets-Need Input dragonfly stitchyphish

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 08:22PM redskies wrote: Marsha- my onc discussed estrogen treatments as a way to re-sensitize tumors that had been sucessfully treated with anti-hormonals for a long time.  Not an option for me, as I've never really had any success on them, but research has shown estrogen to be effective at shrinking tumors, and at reversing resistance to anti-hormonals.  Here's an article on the subject: www.businessweek.com/lifestyle...
Posts.Title: Calling All Liver Mets-Need Input dragonfly stitchyphish

Posts.Content: May 14, 2010 05:58PM redskies wrote: I was having some balance problems so had a brain mri.  It was stressful and hard waiting for the results (got a call 10am the next day.)  It turned out I had fluid in the sinuses near my ears and that was the cause of the balance problems.  Was very glad to have the results!  I look at them as a baseline, just in case.  Plus, I'd always rather know than not.
Posts.Title: Would you want to know? daisylego konakat

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 10:12AM redskies wrote: I was on xeloda for 4 months, do not recall having any colds or problems with infections. I was on the 7 day on/ 7 day off schedule, which sounds like the best one- research shows most of the anti-cancer effects occur during the first 7 days. Had to decrease the dose and then quit because of hand-foot syndrome (which started very early for me,) but it made my liver mets disappear! I also had pretty bad fatigue with xeloda- the only other se I had.  It would get worse 2-3 days into the on cycle, and linger a few days after ending the cycle... still fatigued on the off days, but no where near as bad as during the on days.  So, whether the xeloda has an immune system effect or not, I could see the fatigue (or any other se) making recovering from a cold or infection seem to take longer than normal.  If you do have problems with fatigue, check to see if you can get a rx for a stimulant like ritalin or adderral- I found they helped.  Good luck to you all, Lynne
Posts.Title: xeloda and immune system Sunshine32 steelrose

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2011 10:24PM redskies wrote:  I was on the double shot dose of faslodex for 6 months and had no hair loss; same for femara.  Did lose all of my hair from whole brain rads... it started to noticeably thin during the second week, and by the end of the week it was gone- started to come out in huge clumps, which lasted 2 days. You might be losing the hair due to the incredible stress of a new stage 4 Dx, so you might want to wait on cutting it.  Can't remember when it was, but I did have this happen for a while, then it stopped. So sorry you are having to go through this... can you get in to see a counselor who specializes in working with cancer patients?  I'm very lucky to have a wonderful therapist, always feel better after talking with him.  Lynne
Posts.Title: Hair loss on Faslodex? sandilee redskies

Posts.Content: May 9, 2010 02:46PM - edited May 9, 2010 02:47PM by redskies tooyoung is right, the effects are cumulative.   I had to hold and decrease doses my first week, and after 6 weeks (3 cycles of one week on and one week off) my cat showed regression :)  I've seen a lot of new studies that have found good results with all sorts of doses (some very low) and different schedules, so I'm sure you'll be ok!  I set a cell phone alarm, cause it is easy to forget!
Posts.Title: i missed a dose of xeloda!! bkglenn50 bkglenn50

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 01:58AM redskies wrote: Coming from a biased position, being in a phase 1 trial... I know I read somewhere in all the paperwork (maybe the informed consent?) that the goal of the study is "treatment,"and also that I get to continue to receive the drugs until disease progression, unacceptable se, or the drugs are no longer available. I am left wondering, after reading the article you linked to, does the proposed one year limit on testing in women with stage 4 mean I would be kicked out of the study after it had been in place for a year? I seem to remember reading somewhere that in Europe women w/ stage 4 are actively encouraged to do early phase trials, and it seems to help move research and testing along, compared w/ the US, where all sorts of obstacles are put in the way- needing insurance company permission, being disqualified for many studies if "heavily pre-treated" (wtf? how many people w/ stage 4 aren't?)  I'd really love to see that requirement thrown out of most clinical trials- it is a slap in the face to anyone stage 4 that makes it obvious that any "cures" coming down the line are not specifically intended for people w/ stage 4 bc. Since my last ct showed progression back in my liver after my third try with anti-hormonals, I knew the choice was chemo or nothing (bummer.)  Was set to try abraxane, but when told I qualified for this research study, I felt such hope!  Herceptin, a monoclonal antibody (like the study drug I am taking,) has greatly improved the lives of so many women... and I'm guessing the first women to benefit from it where those in the phase I/II trials.  So, I at least have hope that I might get in at the ground level for a great new treatment, and that means a lot to me... and it helps make up for being used essentially as a human guinea pig... and, someone has to be among the first to try it out!  I am sure my motivation is a lot higher than someone at an earlier stage- I never imagined myself in a phase 1 trial... until the last ct scan. I do agree with your concerns re the Komen foundation and have gotten the impression they do very little for those w/ stage 4... apparently they light luminary candles in our memory... yeah, thanks but no f-ing thanks.  I guess that's about as much in the picture as stage 4 gets w/ Komen (no, wait, I'll be really cynical- I think they also use us as a scare tactic to raise money.) Another complaint- the American Cancer Society's program where newly dx are paired with a "survivor" for support.... no, they did not have anyone with stage 4 I could speak with- talk about good intentions paving the road to hell!  Just like with everyone else, we seem to be an uncomfortable after thought. How about Komen taking care of any travel and other expenses associated with participating in a clinical trial?  And providing a real live human being to call persons just dx w/ bc to screen for appropriate trials, explain what is involved, and recommend clinical trials that might be of interest? Maybe they could use some of that money they're spending to sue other non-profits for having the nerve to use the color pink!  (again, wtf?) Clinicaltrials.gov lets you search by study sponsor, here's what I found for Komen: clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results...  Out of 23 studies (but only 10 actively recruiting) it seems a stretch to suggest any are "cure" oriented (not in my probable lifetime, anyway.)  On a fun note, I did hear of a group of metsters referring to themselves as "stage 5- stayin' alive!"  Wish I could give credit where due, but don't know the names.  Catchy, and oh so true!
Posts.Title: Stage IV Research Lowrider54 Lowrider54

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2010 01:49PM - edited Apr 25, 2010 01:51PM by redskies Hi Tamara, was just reading this, thought you might like it as well- lays out all the current tx options and new potential tx's in a nicely organized way:  Recent advances in systemic therapy. When HER2 is not the target: advances in the treatment of HER2-negative metastatic breast cancer http://breast-cancer-research.com/content/11/4/208 Meds for depression and anxiety, speaking with a psychologist who specializes in oncology, and getting a second opinion, all helped me a lot. Lynne
Posts.Title: Angry, Sad and Scared... llanabeth Frapp

Posts.Content: redskies wrote: After 6 months on femara as my initial treatment I have just begun xeloda.  Was Dx stage 4 lobular from the start; liver mets confirmed by biopsy, and now progression into one or more abdominal nodes. After one day (two doses), my finger tips and toes became red - I was told I should have called at that point.  Took one more day of the initial dose, then went in later that morning and saw my onc, who said it was hand/foot syndrome and decreased my dosage to 1,500 mg twice daily and prescribed 200mg B6 daily. After one day on the lowered dose, I noticed a 2x3 inch area of small raised red dots (no pain or itching) on my left shin and called my onc's nurse, who said to come in.  A couple hours later, when I saw the nurse practitioner, the dots on my shin were an even brighter red and very visibly raised, the soles of my feet were dark mottled red, with mild edema in fingertips and feet along with sensitivity (but no pain of tingling.) The nurse practitioner, who has worked with bc patients for years, said it was definitely h/f, that she had never seen anything like the h/f reaction on my shin... and that I must be a "slow metabolizer" of xeloda.  She took photos of my shin and feet for my file, then brought in another person to confer with.  Both were quite surprised by how quickly this occurred.  After talking with my onc by phone, she told me to discontinue the xeloda for the rest of my "on" week, go ahead and take the "off" week, and then see my onc at the start of the second "on" week, when she would probably put me on a lower dose of xeloda. I was also told to limit my intake of folate, to discontinue my vitamin supplement, and avoid cereal and breads etc. fortified with folic acid... which is surprisingly (and depressingly) hard to do, being a vegetarian. Has anyone else had or heard of a similar experience, or heard anything about "slow metabolizers" of xeloda?  I looked at some research that suggests certain genetic variations affect how xeloda is metabolized, but have not yet found anything else.  I have had no other side effects from xeloda so far, and really hope I can tolerate this drug long term... my onc says she has patients who have been on it for years... oh how I hope I will be in that group, too! Thanks so much, Lynne Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: "slow metabolizer" of xeloda? (h/f syndrome after 2 doses) redskies chainsawz

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 06:22PM redskies wrote: After being diagnosed and undergoing a liver biopsy, I decided moving to a ground floor apt instead of my third floor walk-up was probably a good idea. Found the "perfect" place, moved in, then realized I am living not even a block from a crematorium!  Aaaagggghhh!!!!  Told my BF to just drag me on over there after I quit kickin- why pay for transportation? :)   Still haven't quite gotten over that, yet.  Can't remember what I'm doing half the time (the "why did I get up and walk into this room?" kinda thing,) yet my brain refuses to forget this! As bad, if not worse, was the postcard from the lab I went to after finding my lump, reminding me that my annual mammo was due!  Called and explained very politely that since I'd had a bilateral mx due to bc, would they please remove my name from their mailing list?  (that was a short phone call- the woman felt terrible... maybe almost as bad as I did!) I laugh, I cry, I sometimes even manage both at the same time!  Chocolate, strawberry wine handmade by my BF, more chocolate, antidepressants, chill pills, good friends.... just keep em all coming!  (and yes, I know I probably shouldn't mix the wine in with all that, but how can I refuse?  It's free! It's delicious!  There's still a couple hundred bottles in the cellar!  Heck, might get run over by a truck tomorrow, but I'll be happy tonight!)
Posts.Title: Mail today cookie97 justjudie

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2011 10:14PM - edited Jun 17, 2011 10:55PM by redskies This uncertainty is perhaps the hardest thing about living with a stage 4 Dx.  You want to know what we all want to know, but there are no answers for us to know. There are only signs and trends. Emotionally, it is like riding a roller coaster blind-folded. The shock you are feeling is normal and will fade.  But it can return again in a heartbeat- it did for me when brain mets were accidently found on a ct of my neck. Was scheduled for 14 Tx's of whole brain radiation, at mind-blowing speed. But good news comes again! After my first cycle of abraxane, an enlarged lymph node shrank noticeably! And up into the sky I fly on my cancer rollercoaster!  But for how long....major scanxiety forecast near the end of the month- especially the day before my first ct since starting abraxane. March's ct was a mixed bag of regression and progression (oh, yeah, and brain mets.)  So while I hope both my liver and nodes show regression this time, and I am planning on good news, I know it might not be. Instead of riding higher on that emotional rollercoaster I may come screaming down... there's no way to know in advance. I think part of wanting to know what to expect comes from the intense desire to regain some sense (or illusion) of control-  wanting to "plan" your life, thinking we know what to expect... like we all did in our pre-stage 4 life. Maybe finding out I have brain mets just totally blew away any lingering illusions regarding how much "control" I have... and how much more dependent on others I am, and will be. I know this, feel this, on a fundamentally deeper level than before. I have tried to use this to deal emotionally with not knowing what to expect by focusing on what I can still do. Cancer is what it is. It will do what it will... and so will I! There's a fairly high statistical probablity this will kill me, sooner than later.  But, I'm used to being statistically abnormal... so, I'm gonna dig my heals in and hang on as long as I want to. And when it's time to go, I am only returning to where I came from. But got no plans for leavin anytime soon!   Too many things to still feel and do, see and hear, listen and say... Sorry if this is rambling... and hope it is some help.  This is my life- stage 5, staying alive  Lynne
Posts.Title: Newly restaged to IV BeachyQueen sarah1968uk

Posts.Content: May 10, 2010 01:56AM redskies wrote: Daisy, I am so sorry.  I was dx stage 4 with liver mets this past Aug not long after my mx.  From my experiences, I will say... cry when you are ready.  You will feel better.  Distraction and denial are good... you will need the mental and emotional breaks!  It takes time, but the roller coaster will slow down, the twists and turns will become more predictable.  And when they catch you by surprise, you'll find it gets easier to re-orient yourself.  There will be bad days but there will be many, many beautiful ones as well.  C'est la vie! Wishing you, and all those you hold dear, peace, love, happiness and strength. Lynne
Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2010 09:58AM redskies wrote: I received an email (below) this morning, but am still really turned off by this whole experience. I still feel as if this is in a way a scam- especially when I was asked at the end of the survey if I am now more likely to speak to my onc, do research on avastin, or speak to family/friends about avastin (I was asked the same question at the start of the "survey.")  What other purpose is there for a question like that, other than to measure how much I was persuaded by taking the "survey?" What better way to target your marketing dollars than to wave a $50 bill in front of someone's face, then have them complete a "survey" that does everything it can to persuade them avastin is some miracle drug that will save their life... pretty good deal, considering the profit Genentech/Roche stands to reap from one single person taking avastin. I really don't even know if I want their blood money now- I hate for them to keep it, but I don't want to give them my address or name, and I hate that they have my email address. I wish I had never participated in this.  _______________________________________________________________________________  Thank you for sharing your opinion & insight with us by completing Synovate Healthcare's market research study for Metastatic Cancer! Please except my apologies, as it has come to my attention that you may not have been properly redirected to our honoraria page to enter your information for payment. If you would kindly forward your mailing address to me, I will have your $50 check issued promptly. Again, thank you for your time, it is highly valued! If you have any other questions, please don't hesitate to contact me! Cheri Hric Project Manager, Field Services Synovate Healthcare 1200 MacArthur Blvd, 3rd Floor Mahwah, NJ 07430 201.574.8131 direct 800.980.3999 toll free 201.529.2659 fax 7:00am - 2:30pm in office hours
Posts.Title: Re: Interview Opportunity: Metastatic Breast Cancer... redskies Helmie

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2010 02:22PM redskies wrote: The moderators have pulled the survey for now, the following is posted in the Mods forum: Hello All, We are so sorry about some of the issues, and misunderstandings with the survey. We have decided to pull it down until we can address the issues. If you completed the survey, you WILL be reimbursed. We are so sorry that this was so unclear. Till Monday.... Melissa AnnNYC, I agree completely, this is exactly what it seems like.  Madalyn made a similar comment on the mod forum thread about it resembling targeted advertising. MJLToday, good suggestion about what to do with the money!  Lynne

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2010 10:37AM redskies wrote: No pain, and liver function tests are all good.
Posts.Title: question for all with liver mets. skigrl Wally333

Posts.Content: redskies wrote: As far as I can tell, having heard nor seen anything to change my initial impression, this is a scam, and a pretty heartless and pathetic one at that.  I originally posted about this on the Moderators forum, "Re: Synovate survey" yesterday.  Have heard nothing from the mods yet, so reposted with a different topic title to hopefully catch people's attention.  As we are the targets of this scam, I am reposting here, with an added bit of rant (yeah, I'm mad.) There is no indication I will receive the stated reimbursement for completing the survey, and as far as I can tell, the only purpose of the survey (which is solely a marketing survey) is to persuade people- especially those taking the survey- to sell them on pushing to add avastin (bevacizumab) to their treatment. It mentions unnamed studies which supposedly show great benefit from taking avastin... problem is, the "benefit" as best I can tell from my own research, is minimal in terms of overall survival; the SE were also very downplayed. And, avastin is very very expensive. My onc has already mentioned to me that although avastin seems to do what it is intended to do, there is no good proof that it offers much in the real world setting- the article below covers this topic: Hurdling the Challenges of Anti-angiogenic Therapy by Caroline Helwick Clinical Oncology News ISSUE: APRIL, 2010 | VOLUME: 05:04 http://www.clinicaloncology.com/index.asp?section_id=148&show=dept&issue_id=625&article_id=15024 I want to make clear, because I know there are people on this forum who have had good results with the chemo/avastin combo, that I don't mean to take anything away from their happiness. I truly and only wish them (and all of us) the best of luck... Oh how we all wish for a cure!   This is all directed solely towards the way in which this marketing "interview" is being conducted and promoted, and by what I read in the article below regarding the cost of tx with avastin.  The article is 4 years old, but it appears the only thing that has changed is the level of optimism regarding avastin's efficacy: A Cancer Drug Shows Promise, at a Price That Many Can't Pay New York Times 2/15/06 http://www.nytimes.com/2006/02/15/business/15drug.html?_r=1 [Side rant:  especially irritating is that according to the NYT article, the cost of making the drug is a fraction of what Genentech/Roche sells it for; and, that initial pricing was based on the amount of the drug used by weight to treat colon cancer... BUT, the dose by weight used in bc tx is greater, and instead of charging a similar price per tx, the company continues to charge by weight.  Now, I have no problems with companies making a reasonable profit, but I think charging the equivalent of $100,000 per year for a treatment that has little proof it does much for most  people with bc in the real world is obscene!] Until I hear anything different, all I can say is please DON'T TAKE PART IN THIS! P.S. Oh yeah, and to Genentech/Roche (makers of Avastin / bevacizumab) and Synovate... my experience with this has resulted in the exact opposite of the intent of whoever came up with this piece of B.S. I now have absolutely nothing good to say about any of this!!!!! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Re: Interview Opportunity: Metastatic Breast Cancer... redskies Helmie

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2010 08:14PM - edited Apr 13, 2010 08:33PM by redskies I think you should talk to the bride, let her know the wardrobe problems you are having and ask her to choose a style you feel good in- she may not realize where you're at, same for the others. right after my bilat mx (used to be a 40D), it was as if I finally noticed there were breasts everywhere I looked!  remember looking at my bf's man boobs (especially his nips) in amazement.... smiled, and asked if I could play with his breasts!  yes, breasts are amazing, but I never considered implants or prosthetics...  I personally would feel uncomfortable doing so for a number of reasons... but yes, I still cried first time I went shopping this spring.  Don't miss wearing or shopping for bras, but there is a certain nostalgia there, and a little sadness. have happily decided to go with sleaveless cotton t's in place of bras- much more comfy, and much less expensive! P.S. No offense to anyone making a different choice, but doesn't it seem that implants or prosthetics ultimately run counter to breast cancer "awareness?"
Posts.Title: Bride's maid blues KSkier redwoman

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 04:24PM - edited Jan 16, 2011 05:37PM by redskies Hi Lisa, I just posted a long response to windtalker's questions, then noticed yours... I'll add just a little more here. I would really question the 2 week on and 1 off schedule- I think the research is pretty strong that the most benefit in terms of anti-tumor activity occurs within the first 7 days of the cycle, the extra days are thought to produce little benefit and make the side effects worse... it worked great for me, but I had to stop because of the hand-foot syndrome (hfs.).  If it works for you, I would view it as a long haul, do everything you can to keep the side effects from developing. HFS can start after your first dose, which happened to me, and it will get worse over time, but also went away quickly once I stopped taking xeloda.  Call your doc asap, you may be told to hold a dose or two, or decrease dosage. I know I felt the same kind of fear when I started that you mentioned, and for the same reason (I think we all go through that... anything that makes it all seem more real, or like another step down a dark and scary path.)  Putting that first pill in my mouth was so hard, but hearing the word "regression" for the first time since this all started shot me straight up to cloud nine! Hope all is going well for you! Lynne P.S. Forgot to mention I did also have problems with fatigue, it would start a couple days into the on cycle and last a couple into the off cycle (I was on the 7 day on/7 day off cycle.)  Was already taking ritalin for memory issues, after describing the fatigue to my psych he switched me to a higher dose of adderral for the bad fatigue days, and a smaller dose of adderral for the easier days- helped quite a bit.
Posts.Title: Xeloda--"real life" se's lisa34lisa redskies

Posts.Content: May 13, 2010 07:36PM redskies wrote: Hi, I've been taking xeloda for a few months now, main problems are hfs and fatigue.  Decreasing the dose is often needed due to se, but research shows many have good results with lower than the usual starting dose.  Despite dose reductions due to the se, I had regression in my first ct done after 3 cycles (one week on and one week off.)  no nausea, diarrhea, etc.  from what I've read hfs is worse with xeloda than with 5-FU because it is in your system longer... 100mg vitamin B6 twice daily and watching your dietary folate/folic acid intake are suggested if you get hfs (no multi-vitamins, watch out for things like Total cereal.)  There's a long xeloda thread in the stage 4 forum if you are interested.  Hope you've had a good first week!
Posts.Title: Xeloda, anyone? lindamsn lindamsn

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2011 07:45AM - edited Jun 18, 2011 08:01AM by redskies Dear Deborah, I am so sorry to hear of your stage 4 diagnosis.  You are not over-reacting.  Its a different world, and the journey there is unimaginable by anyone who hasn't experienced it. I see a psychologist through my cancer center who only treats people with cancer, it has helped very much (its a new field called psycho-oncology.) On the good side, as my oncologist would say, you're "young" like me (though I understand feeling sooo aged by all of this) and you have what sounds like a "low disease burden." as do I. Have you had a cat scan done since you started the faslodex?  You should probably be getting one cat scan every 2-3 months. You need some idea if the faslodex is working- I am ER+/PR- /her2 neg, and have been on faslodex double shots... slowed the progression but you can only go so long down that road.  Plus, the er/pr/her status can change when it returns as mets, and the only way to know is by biopsy... ask if one can be done (and press hard if the answer is no... unless none of nodes are accessible- and get a second opinion.)  Your treatment options will change if the er/pr/her status has changed, and this is not rare. If at all possible, get a second opinion asap from a different oncologist.  Some are very, very good when talking with their patients, others do a lousy job. Look around- you shouldn't have to pry info out of your oncologist!  Mine has the most wonderful smile, has an awesome nurse coordinator who calls back the same day with answers to questions or concerns I leave on her voice mail, and the  staff are friendly and happy too... and they all leave me feeling better!   I was diagnosed stage 4 based on the level of lymph nodes with cancer after surgery.  Wasted 4 months at the first place I was treated- substandard care in so many ways. Went for a second opinion at a large teaching and research hospital, and was knocked flat by the difference. The Dr. sat at eye level with me, and made me feel he had nothing else in the world to do at that time but talk with me and get to know me and  my story. However long it took.  Explained everything in depth, looked to see I understood, asked for questions from me...WOW! Think about getting SSDI if you can- it is automatic for breast cancer stage 4- the day you are diagnosed is the day you become eligible (for me it was the date of my biopsy.) They back date the 6 month (?) waiting period to that date too. After 2 years on SSDI you are automatically enrolled in Medicare.  You can't work and get SSDI, but you can make your job taking care of yourself (and helping your husband... he'll be in need of some support, understanding, and stress relief, too.) Most important though is to remember that each person's cancer is different and statistics about prognosis only apply at the group level (plus they are only describing the way in which a group responded overall at some time in the past.)  The only thing that matters is how your cancer responds to treatment. Best wishes and hopes for you, Lynne  P.S. It is true, it does get better...
Posts.Title: Newly restaged to IV BeachyQueen sarah1968uk

Oh how we all wish for a cure!   This is all directed solely towards the way in which this marketing "interview" is being conducted and promoted, and by what I read in the article below regarding the cost of tx with avastin.  The article is 4 years old, but it appears the only thing that has changed is the level of optimism regarding avastin's efficacy: A Cancer Drug Shows Promise, at a Price That Many Can't Pay New York Times 2/15/06 http://www.nytimes.com/2006/02/15/business/15drug.html?_r=1 [Side rant:  especially irritating is that according to the NYT article, the cost of making the drug is a fraction of what Genentech/Roche sells it for; and, that initial pricing was based on the amount of the drug used by weight to treat colon cancer... BUT, the dose by weight used in bc tx is greater, and instead of charging a similar price per tx, the company continues to charge by weight.  Now, I have no problems with companies making a reasonable profit, but I think charging the equivalent of $100,000 per year for a treatment that has little proof it does much for most  people with bc in the real world is obscene!] Until I hear anything different, all I can say is please DON'T TAKE PART IN THIS! P.S. Oh yeah, and to Genentech/Roche (makers of Avastin / bevacizumab) and Synovate... my experience with this has resulted in the exact opposite of the intent of whoever came up with this piece of B.S. I now have absolutely nothing good to say about any of this!!!!! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Re: Interview Opportunity: Metastatic Breast Cancer... redskies Helmie

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2010 11:22PM redskies wrote: This is (was) a great site, have seen it before, but, I think the most recent study on the main page is from  2006, which is a long, long time in research terms.  The most recent newsletter is dated Oct 2008, also pretty old, and there are a number of dead links.  I wish the info was newer, the person behind it did a very good job of integrating and explaining the research from what I recall. I usually go to google scholar and pubmed for info: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed  The asco and sabc sites are good, too, and then there's always the Mayo, MDAnderson, and Sloan-Kettering sites. Wishing your daughter good luck, Riverhorse. Lynne
Posts.Title: Information on MBC riverhorse redskies

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2010 02:20AM redskies wrote: I had to decrease my dose to 2000mg xeloda due to hand-foot syndrome, and have had possibly a complete remission of liver and abdominal lymph node mets (2 new mesenteric lymph nodes showed up on the ct scan, but I'd also just had a fever- and the nodes under my chin were swollen from that, so I suspect the new nodes are probably B9 swelling.) I've seen a lot of recent studies finding low doses effective- I get the feeling no one knows just how low you can go on the dose; and since the side effects are dose related, low is good!
Posts.Title: isnt 2000mg xeloda low dose marieibrahim redskies
